poem:
### Five Years After

The pavement echoes memories,  
marches softening in time's embrace.  
Belief once a loud, unified chorus,  
now a whisper—tired, dispersed.  
Yet the streets remember footprints,  
each step a protest, a question.  
What fades is not the cry,  
but the listening heart,  
mute to the echo  
that still rises within us.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "US adults’ belief in impact of BLM protests consistently decreased since 2020 – study This 25 May marks the fifth anniversary of the police killing of George Floyd, a Black man in Minneapolis, Minnesota, whose murder sparked international protests against police brutality and racism. A new study by the Pew Institute examines the beliefs of American adults regarding race and racial issues five years after Floyd’s death. In June 2020, 67% of US adults expressed". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
